property.name: Background
property.value: The Bulgars, a Central Asian Turkic tribe, merged with the local Slavic inhabitants in the late 7th century to form the first Bulgarian state. In succeeding centuries, Bulgaria struggled with the Byzantine Empire to assert its place in the Balkans, but by the end of the 14th century the country was overrun by the Ottoman Turks. Northern Bulgaria attained autonomy in 1878 and all of Bulgaria became independent from the Ottoman Empire in 1908. Having fought on the losing side in both World Wars, Bulgaria fell within the Soviet sphere of influence and became a People's Republic in 1946. Communist domination ended in 1990, when Bulgaria held its first multiparty election since World War II and began the contentious process of moving toward political democracy and a market economy while combating inflation, unemployment, corruption, and crime. The country joined NATO in 2004 and the EU in 2007.

property.name: Location
property.value: Southeastern Europe, bordering the Black Sea, between Romania and Turkey

property.name: Area - comparative
property.value: almost identical in size to Virginia; slightly larger than Tennessee

subproperty.name: border countries (5)
subproperty.value: Greece 472 km, Macedonia 162 km, Romania 605 km, Serbia 344 km, Turkey 223 km

property.name: Climate
property.value: temperate; cold, damp winters; hot, dry summers

property.name: Terrain
property.value: mostly mountains with lowlands in north and southeast

property.name: Natural resources
property.value: bauxite, copper, lead, zinc, coal, timber, arable land

property.name: Land use
property.value: arable land 29.9%; permanent crops 1.5%; permanent pasture 15.5%

property.name: Population - distribution
property.value: a fairly even distribution throughout most of the country, with urban areas attracting larger populations

property.name: Environment - current issues

subproperty.name: party to
subproperty.value: Air Pollution, Air Pollution-Nitrogen Oxides, Air Pollution-Persistent Organic Pollutants, Air Pollution-Sulfur 85, Air Pollution-Sulfur 94, Air Pollution-Volatile Organic Compounds, Antarctic-Environmental Protocol, Antarctic-Marine Living Resources, Antarctic Treaty, Biodiversity, Climate Change, Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol, Desertification, Endangered Species, Environmental Modification, Hazardous Wastes, Law of the Sea, Marine Dumping, Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, Wetlands

property.name: Geography - note
property.value: strategic location near Turkish Straits; controls key land routes from Europe to Middle East and Asia

property.name: Ethnic groups
property.value: Bulgarian 76.9%, Turkish 8%, Romani 4.4%, other 0.7% (including Russian, Armenian, and Vlach), other (unknown) 10% (2011 est.)

subproperty.name: note
subproperty.value: Romani populations are usually underestimated in official statistics and may represent 9â€“11% of Bulgaria's population

property.name: Languages
property.value: Bulgarian (official) 76.8%, Turkish 8.2%, Romani 3.8%, other 0.7%, unspecified 10.5% (2011 est.)

property.name: Religions
property.value: Eastern Orthodox 59.4%, Muslim 7.8%, other (including Catholic, Protestant, Armenian Apostolic Orthodox, and Jewish) 1.7%, none 3.7%, unspecified 27.4% (2011 est.)

property.name: Population distribution
property.value: a fairly even distribution throughout most of the country, with urban areas attracting larger populations

property.name: s mean age at first birth

subproperty.name: definition
subproperty.value: age 15 and over can read and write

property.name: School life expectancy (primary to tertiary education)

subproperty.name: etymology
subproperty.value: named after the Bulgar tribes who settled the lower Balkan region in the 7th century A.D.

subproperty.name: time difference
subproperty.value: UTC+2 (7 hours ahead of Washington, DC, during Standard Time)

subproperty.name: daylight saving time
subproperty.value: +1hr, begins last Sunday in March; ends last Sunday in October

property.name: Administrative divisions
property.value: 28 provinces (oblasti, singular - oblast); Blagoevgrad, Burgas, Dobrich, Gabrovo, Haskovo, Kardzhali, Kyustendil, Lovech, Montana, Pazardzhik, Pernik, Pleven, Plovdiv, Razgrad, Ruse, Shumen, Silistra, Sliven, Smolyan, Sofia, Sofia-Grad (Sofia City), Stara Zagora, Targovishte, Varna, Veliko Tarnovo, Vidin, Vratsa, Yambol

property.name: Independence
property.value: 3 March 1878 (as an autonomous principality within the Ottoman Empire); 22 September 1908 (complete independence from the Ottoman Empire)

subproperty.name: history
subproperty.value: several previous; latest drafted between late 1990 and early 1991, adopted 13 July 1991

subproperty.name: amendments
subproperty.value: proposed by the National Assembly or by the president of the republic; passage requires three-fourths majority vote of National Assembly members in three ballots; signed by the National Assembly chairperson; note - under special circumstances, a "Grand National Assembly" is elected with the authority to write a new constitution and amend certain articles of the constitution, including those affecting basic civil rights and national sovereignty; passage requires at least two-thirds majority vote in each of several readings; amended several times, last in 2015 (2016)

property.name: International law organization participation
property.value: accepts compulsory ICJ jurisdiction with reservations; accepts ICCt jurisdiction

subproperty.name: citizenship by descent only
subproperty.value: at least one parent must be a citizen of Bulgaria

subproperty.name: chief of state
subproperty.value: President Rumen RADEV (since 22 January 2017); Vice President Iliana YOTOVA (since 22 January 2017)

subproperty.name: head of government
subproperty.value: Prime Minister Boyko BORISSOV (since 4 May 2017); note - BORISSOV served 2 previous terms as prime minister (27 July 2009-13 March 2013 and 7 November 2014-27 January 2017)

subproperty.name: cabinet
subproperty.value: Council of Ministers nominated by the prime minister, elected by the National Assembly

subproperty.name: appointments
subproperty.value: president and vice president elected on the same ballot by absolute majority popular vote in 2 rounds if needed for a 5-year term (eligible for a second term); election last held on 6 and 13 November 2016 (next to be held in fall 2021); chairman of the Council of Ministers (prime minister) elected by the National Assembly; deputy prime ministers nominated by the prime minister, elected by the National Assembly

subproperty.name: election results
subproperty.value: Rumen RADEV elected president in second round; percent of vote - Rumen RADEV (independent, supported by Bulgarian Socialist Party) 59.4%, Tsetska TSACHEVA (GERB) 36.2%, neither 4.5%; Boyko BORISSOV (GERB) elected prime minister; National Assembly vote - 133 to 100

subproperty.name: description
subproperty.value: unicameral National Assembly or Narodno Sabranie (240 seats; members directly elected in multi-seat constituencies by proportional representation vote to serve 4-year terms)

subproperty.name: elections
subproperty.value: last held on 26 March 2017 (next to be held spring 2021)

subproperty.name: election results
subproperty.value: percent of vote by party/coalition - GERB 32.7%, BSP 27.2%, United Patriots 9.1%, DPS 9%, Volya 4.2%, other 17.8%; seats by party/coalition - GERB 95, BSP 80, United Patriots 27, DPS 26, Volya 12

subproperty.name: highest court(s)
subproperty.value: Supreme Court of Cassation (consists of a chairman and approximately 72 judges organized into penal, civil, and commercial colleges); Supreme Administrative Court (organized in 2 colleges with various panels of 5 judges each); Constitutional Court (consists of 12 justices); note - Constitutional Court resides outside the judiciary

subproperty.name: judge selection and term of office
subproperty.value: Supreme Court of Cassation and Supreme Administrative judges elected by the Supreme Judicial Council or SJC (consists of 25 members with extensive legal experience) and appointed by the president; judges can serve until mandatory retirement at age 65; Constitutional Court justices elected by the National Assembly and appointed by the president and the SJC; justices appointed for 9-year terms with renewal of 4 justices every 3 years

subproperty.name: subordinate courts
subproperty.value: appeals courts; regional and district courts; administrative courts; courts martial

subproperty.name: other
subproperty.value: numerous regional, ethnic, and national interest groups with various agendas

property.name: International organization participation
property.value: Australia Group, BIS, BSEC, CD, CE, CEI, CERN, EAPC, EBRD, ECB, EIB, EU, FAO, G- 9, IAEA, IBRD, ICAO, ICC (national committees), ICCt, ICRM, IDA, IFC, IFRCS, IHO (pending member), ILO, IMF, IMO, IMSO, Interpol, IOC, IOM, IPU, ISO, ITU, ITUC (NGOs), MIGA, NATO, NSG, OAS (observer), OIF, OPCW, OSCE, PCA, SELEC, UN, UNCTAD, UNESCO, UNHCR, UNIDO, UNMIL, UNWTO, UPU, WCO, WFTU (NGOs), WHO, WIPO, WMO, WTO, ZC

subproperty.name: mailing address
subproperty.value: American Embassy Sofia, US Department of State, 5740 Sofia Place, Washington, DC 20521-5740

property.name: Flag description
property.value: three equal horizontal bands of white (top), green, and red; the pan-Slavic white-blue-red colors were modified by substituting a green band (representing freedom) for the blue

subproperty.name: note
subproperty.value: the national emblem, formerly on the hoist side of the white stripe, has been removed

property.name: National symbol(s)
property.value: lion; national colors: white, green, red

subproperty.name: note
subproperty.value: adopted 1964; composed in 1885 by a student en route to fight in the Serbo-Bulgarian War

property.name: Economy - overview
property.value: Despite a favorable investment regime, including low, flat corporate income taxes, significant challenges remain. Corruption in public administration, a weak judiciary, low productivity, and the presence of organized crime continue to hamper the country's investment climate and economic prospects.

property.name: Agriculture - products
property.value: vegetables, fruits, tobacco, wine, wheat, barley, sunflowers, sugar beets; livestock

property.name: Industries
property.value: electricity, gas, water; food, beverages, tobacco; machinery and equipment, automotive parts, base metals, chemical products, coke, refined petroleum, nuclear fuel; outsourcing centers

property.name: Household income or consumption by percentage share
Distribution of family income - Gini index

subproperty.name: note
subproperty.value: defined by the EU's Maastricht Treaty as consolidated general government gross debt at nominal value, outstanding at the end of the year in the following categories of government liabilities: currency and deposits, securities other than shares excluding financial derivatives, and loans; general government sector comprises the subsectors: central government, state government, local government, and social security funds

subproperty.name: note
subproperty.value: Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) has had no independent monetary policy since the introduction of the Currency Board regime in 1997; this is BNB's base interest rate

property.name: Market value of publicly traded shares
Exports - commodities

property.name: Exports - partners
property.value: Germany 13.7%, Italy 9.3%, Romania 8.8%, Turkey 7.9%, Greece 7%, France 4.5% (2016)

property.name: Imports - commodities
property.value: machinery and equipment; metals and ores; chemicals and plastics; fuels, minerals, and raw materials

property.name: Imports - partners
property.value: Germany 13.1%, Russia 8.9%, Italy 7.9%, Romania 7%, Turkey 6.2%, Greece 4.8%, Poland 4.1% (2016)

subproperty.name: general assessment
domestic
subproperty.value: the Bulgaria Telecommunications Company's fixed-line monopoly terminated in 2005 in an effort to upgrade fixed-line services; mobile-cellular teledensity, fostered by multiple service providers, is over 125 telephones per 100 persons

subproperty.name: international
subproperty.value: country code - 359; submarine cable provides connectivity to Ukraine and Russia; a combination submarine cable and land fiber-optic system provides connectivity to Italy, Albania, and Macedonia; satellite earth stations - 3 (1 Intersputnik in the Atlantic Ocean region, 2 Intelsat in the Atlantic and Indian Ocean regions) (2016)

property.name: Broadcast media
property.value: 4 national terrestrial TV stations with 1 state-owned and 3 privately owned; a vast array of TV stations are available from cable and satellite TV providers; state-owned national radio broadcasts over 3 networks; large number of private radio stations broadcasting, especially in urban areas (2010)

subproperty.name: inventory of registered aircraft operated by air carriers
annual passenger traffic on registered air carriers
annual freight traffic on registered air carriers

Pipelines
property.value: gas 2,765 km; oil 346 km; refined products 378 km (2017)

subproperty.name: note
subproperty.value: does not include Category IV local roads (2011)

subproperty.name: by type
subproperty.value: bulk carrier 2, general cargo 18, oil tanker 8, other 52 (2017)

property.name: Military branches
property.value: Bulgarian Armed Forces: Land Forces (aka Army), Naval Forces, Bulgarian Air Forces (Voennovazdyshni Sily, VVS) (2017)

property.name: Military service age and obligation
property.value: 18-27 years of age for voluntary military service; conscription ended in January 2008; service obligation 6-9 months (2012)

subproperty.name: note
subproperty.value: 47,819 estimated refugee and migrant arrivals (January 2015 - January 2018); Bulgaria is predominantly a transit country and hosts approximately 1,800 migrants and asylum seekers as of September 2017

subproperty.name: current situation
subproperty.value: Bulgaria is a source and, to a lesser extent, a transit and destination country for men, women, and children subjected to sex trafficking and forced labor; Bulgaria is one of the main sources of human trafficking in the EU; women and children are increasingly sex trafficked domestically, as well as in Europe, Russia, the Middle East, and the US; adults and children become forced laborers in agriculture, construction, and the service sector in Europe, Israel, and Zambia; Romanian girls are also subjected to sex trafficking in Bulgaria

subproperty.name: tier rating

property.name: Illicit drugs
property.value: major European transshipment point for Southwest Asian heroin and, to a lesser degree, South American cocaine for the European market; limited producer of precursor chemicals; vulnerable to money laundering because of corruption, organized crime; some money laundering of drug-related proceeds through financial institutions
